text.p: Grain and oilseed exports reported by USDA and private export sources.

WHEAT SALE - Two South Korean flour mills, Dongah Flour Mills Co Ltd and Cheiljedang Corp, on Wednesday bought a total of 23,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat from Mitsubishi Corp, traders said. Shipment was set for October 25-November 25 from the Pacific Northwest to the western port city of Inchon.

WHEAT TENDER - Taiwan's Provincial Food Bureau will tender on August 28 for a 15,470-tonne shipment of U.S. No.1 wheat, grain traders said. The shipment would be slated for delivery from the Pacific Northwest between October 1 and 20.
- World Food Programme officials said this week the Bangladesh government planned commercial imports of 100,000 tonnes of soft wheat for November shipment.
"But the purchase may be delayed if the present high price of wheat in the international market continues," one said.
- Moldova will tender on August 27 for 35,000 tonnes of U.S. hard red winter wheat to be financed by Title I PL-480 funding for shipment September 5 and 25.
- The CCC is seeking up to 33,000 tonnes of U.S. No.2 soft white wheat under the donation program to Bangladesh for Sept 10-Oct 5 delivery. Offers are due on August 27.
- The CCC seeks up to 17,000 tonnes of U.S. No.2 Northern Spring/Dark Northern Spring wheat under the export donation program to Nicaragua for Nov 15-Dec 10 shipment.

- Sri Lanka will tender on August 30 for 100,000 tonnes of U.S., Canadian or Argentinian wheat. It includes 50,000 tonnes of soft wheat for September shipment and 50,000 tonnes of hard wheat for October shipment.
- Syria's General Establishment for Cereal Processing and Trade was offering 100,000 tonnes of hard amber durum wheat for sale. The date to receive offers was September 3.
WHEAT TENDER - The CCC seeks up to 16,000 tonnes of U.S. No. 2 hard red winter or soft red winter or soft white wheat under the donation program to Tajikistan for Sept 15-Oct 10 shipment.

- Jordan will tender August 28 for 90,000 tonnes of U.S. HRW or spring wheat and 10,000 tonnes of soft white or SRW wheat for first and second half October shipment, No. 2 or better wheat with option for equivalent origins in two 50,000-tonne lots.
RICE TENDER - Japan plans to buy at least 500 tonnes of Pakistan's super Basmati rice in October or November, exporters said on Wednesday.

SOYBEAN TENDER - Pakistan is seeking 30,000 to 34,000 tonnes U.S. no. 2 or better yellow soybeans under PL 480, Title I. Delivery is slated for October 15-30. Bids must be submitted by August 28 and remain valid until August 29.

WHEAT AND BARLEY TENDER - The Japanese Food Agency will seek overnight 137,000 tonnes of U.S., Canadian and Australian wheat and 40,000 tonnes of Australian feed barley and U.S. or Canadian barley, U.S. Japanese-based exporters said.
Shipment for both the wheat and the barley is set for October 11 to November 10, they said.

BARLEY TENDER - Saudi Arabia is in the world market for 800,000 tonnes of optional-origin feed barley and will hold a tender on August 21, European grain traders said. It seeks 250,000 tonnes for September 25 arrival and 550,000 tonnes for delivery on October 15, they said.
MARKET TALK - Bulgaria is expected to import around 100,000 tonnes of grain worth $25 million from the United States, its trade minister Atanas Paparizov said.
- A U.S. Agriculture Department official said there was no sign of any widespread problem with aflatoxin in U.S. corn grown in Texas and surrounding states.
Concerns were raised on Tuesday by reports from the University of Texas of high levels of aflatoxin contamination in corn harvested along the Texas Gulf Coast.

Corn containing aflatoxin, a potent carcinogen, in excess of 20 parts per billion is barred by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration from human consumption and levels exceeding 300 ppb are barred from livestock use ... Taiwan grain buyers said world corn prices could rise sharply if aflatoxin found in Texas spreads to major northern U.S. corn areas, but Japanese traders shrugged off the worries ... South Korea said it was tightening quarantine procedures for U.S. corn imports.
--Doris Frankel 312-983-7305
